results.title: Duke Ellington and his orchestra
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Good years of jazz”.
Features one of the most famous jazz musicians of our time, Duke Ellington leads his orchestra in some his most popular hits. These include: ‘Take the A train, satin Doll, Blow by blow, Things ain’t what they used to be, VIP boogie and Kinda Dukish.’ Ample time is given to solo performances by many of the fine soloists.

results.title: Tropical lowland: the Amazon River, Brazil
results.creator_credit: Jules Bucher and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of series “The Earth and its peoples”
The Amazon River drains two-fifths of the continent of South America and varies in width from a mile to 800 miles at its mouth. Rain falls nearly every day, the climate hot and humid and the rain forest is almost impenetrable. Travel is almost entirely by water. Products are rosewood, brazil nuts, rubber, jute, cocoa. We are shown a family living in primitive conditions and the effect an unhealthy climate can have upon people and their development.

results.title: The Good years of jazz
results.creator_credit: Bernard Rubin, Mike Bryan and Storyville Films
results.brief_description: In the early 1960’s, the Goodyear tyre company comissioned five short jazz films, featuring a handful of the leading musicians of the day in a move that was not purely philanthropic, but which also acted as part of a promotional campaign.

results.title: Land behind the dikes: the Netherlands
results.creator_credit: John Ferno and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Makes the point that the Netherlands, with about one-half of the land area below sea level, is largely man-made. Illustrates draining, reclamation, farming, the use of canals for transport, and the richness of the polders.

results.title: Cattle and the corn belt
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
The Middle West States of America play an important part in producing the country’s meat supply. Here are the cattle buyers and the packing plants, but the cattle business begins in Montana and Wyoming on the cattle ranches. The film shows the annual roundup, the branding, and the shipments of cattle in the fall to the farmers in the corn belt, where they are fattened for market.

results.title: French Canadians: the St Lawrence Lowland, Quebec
results.creator_credit: J.H. Lenauer and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Looks at life in the village of St Pierre in Quebec, depicting farming and dairying activities which have undergone little change for over three generations.

results.title: Eskimo hunters
results.creator_credit: W. Kay Norton and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Describes the life of the Eskimos of north-western Alaska, 25,000 of whom live in scattered villages in a region in which the winters are six months long.

results.title: Building a nation: Israel
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Changes in the cultures of the earth’s peoples are being brought about today with the advent of modern technologies. Israel, the seat of an ancient culture, illustrates such change. In this semi-arid land irrigation has been a foremost problem. Old methods of subsistence farming with antiquated tools and inadequate irrigation are giving way to modern settlements where irrigation and mechanized farming produce excellent crops. Old cities in which religious influence once predominated are contrasted with modern cities, the major activities of which are the development of trade and industry. Immigrants arriving in Israel today live in cooperative settlements and work on farm lands that have been reclaimed from the desert by modern irrigation.
results.description:

Old cities in which religious influence once predominated are contrasted with modern cities, the major activities of which are the development of trade and industry. Immigrants arriving in Israel today live in cooperative settlements and work on farm lands that have been reclaimed from the desert by modern irrigation.

results.title: An Island nation: Japan
results.creator_credit: Victor Jurgens and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Life in urban and rural Japan, showing the customs and work of a Japanese farm family as observed by their young cousin from the city. Shows how this country of 80,000,000 people, handicapped by mountainous terrain and without the necessary raw materials for industrial development, has done to overcome her difficulties. Japan’s industry is based on the importation of raw materials and the selling of finished products throughout the world, made possible by low wages and long hours of work. In rural areas, people work long and hard to gain a livelihood from the soil.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victor Jurgens and Louis de Rochemont Associates

results.title: An Industrial lake port
results.creator_credit: Victor Vicas and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
The film opens in a lighthouse on the Great Lakes where a sailor from the United States Coast Guard is entertaining a grup of visiting Sea Scouts on a tour of the region. Discusses the various industries that take place on the Great Lakes and how in winter when the lakes freeze over, the crews on the cargo ships must work on ocean-going vessels for part of the year when the lakes are not navigable.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victor Vicas and Louis de Rochemont Associates
